headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to ADP's Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I will now turn the conference over to M
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to ADP's Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I will now turn the conference over to Ms. Elena Charles, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ms. Charles, please go ahead.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. I'm here today with Gary Butler, ADP's President and CEO; and Chris Reidy, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joining us this morning for our Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. A slide presentation acc
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning. I'm here today with Gary Butler, ADP's President and CEO; and Chris Reidy, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joining us this morning for our Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. A slide presentation accompanies today's call and webcast and is available for you to print from the Investor Relations home page of our website at adp.com.  Just to remind you, the quarterly history of revenue and pretax earnings for our reportable segments has been posted to the IR section of our website. These schedules have been updated to include the second quarter of fiscal 2010. During today's conference call, we will make some forward-looking statements that refer to future events and, as such, involve some risks and these are discussed on Page 2 of the slide presentation and in our periodic filings with the SEC. With that, I'll now turn the call over to Gary for his opening remarks.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Elena. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us here today. I'll begin today's call with some opening comments about our second quarter results, then I'll turn the call over to Chris Reidy, our CFO, to take you through the detailed
componenttext: Thank you, Elena. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us here today. I'll begin today's call with some opening comments about our second quarter results, then I'll turn the call over to Chris Reidy, our CFO, to take you through the detailed results. Afterwards, I'll return to provide you with our updated forecast for fiscal 2010. And before we take your questions, I'll provide some concluding remarks.Let me begin. ADP's results for the quarter were pretty much in line with our expectations. The cumulative impact from the difficult economic environment that we've seen over the last 15 months continued to negatively impact our results.  Revenues for the second fiscal quarter of 2010 were flat to a year ago but included a benefit of nearly two percentage points from favorable foreign exchange rates as the dollar weakened during the quarter. However, I am pleased that pretax and net earnings both grew 1%, and earnings per share from continuing operations grew 2%, excluding the favorable tax item that we had in the quarter. I'm also encouraged by our key business metrics. Employer Services new business sales, client retention, client funds balances and the number of pay were all somewhat lower compared with a year ago. The pace of the decline has certainly slowed and in some cases, our key metrics in the quarter were actually better than we expected. We continued to see some indications of stabilization in terms of employment levels in the U.S. And client retention, while still under pressure, leveled off in the quarter. However, as you are aware, the key retention period is third quarter, and until we see those results, we are holding our estimates for the full year of up to a full one point decline.Moving on to sales, although new business sales declined 3% in the second quarter, our salesforce is seeing market receptivity from companies once again willing to invest again in their business. However, the selling environment continues to be somewhat mixed across the business units within Employer Services. Similar to what we told you three months ago, sales cycles for larger companies, particularly in the U.S., remain challenged, and as a result, new business sales in our National Accounts business units were behind our expectations and declined year-over-year. That being said, new business sales to mid-sized companies in our Major Accounts division were flat to a year ago, but continued to be ahead of our expectation. And sales in Europe, our largest international market, were down year-over-year but also ahead of our expectations.New business sales and/ small business services grew year-over-year, which I'm quite pleased with given the sales headcount reductions that were made in last year's fourth quarter. Total store sales, which includes the PEO, were also strong in the quarter with good growth year-over-year. As a result of this positive sales momentum in most of our markets, we are now investing for future growth and have begun the acceleration of next year's salesforce hiring. I believe this will position ADP for stronger sales growth over the next 12 to 18 months. However, we expect this necessary investment will also be a drag on earnings through the same 12 to 18 months period. And let me emphasize this is well worth of investment to increase revenues and in turn, profitability over the longer term. Everything considered, we are also more confident in our ability to achieve the same dollar amount of new business sales as last year or perhaps come in slightly higher than last year.Moving on to Dealer Services. The automotive marketplace is still quite challenged, but on a positive note, December was the second consecutive month of year-to-year increases and U.S. car sales volume. We're not calling it a trend, but it certainly feels a heck of a lot better than the declines over the last couple of years. The industry is certainly not out of the woods as dealership closings continued, but Dealer Services win-loss rates in the marketplace continue to be strong and resulted in increased North American market share for ADP year-over-year. We continue to estimate that dealership closings will be completed over the next 12 months with about $50 million in total of annualized loss revenues in Dealer Services. To date, closed ADP sites represent about 10 million of the 50 million in annualized revenues. By the end of fiscal '10, we expect additional dealership closings representing another $20 million of annualized loss revenues. As these closings will occur throughout this fiscal year, we estimate that the fiscal '10 impact will be about approximately $15 million of loss revenue. Additionally, the larger enterprise accounts have witnessed an increase in activity and are exploring options to expand their market share. We've also seen an increase in the volume of activity when layered applications from the large auto consolidators as they sharpened their operating strategy by improving process and technology. We believe these indicators are all positive signs regarding the future health of the automotive marketplace. With that, I'll turn it over to Chris to provide the details of our results.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. We're on Slide 4. Total revenues of $2.2 billion in the quarter were flat to a year ago and continue to be negatively impacted by the cumulative impact from the difficult economy that began towards the end of Sept
componenttext: Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. We're on Slide 4. Total revenues of $2.2 billion in the quarter were flat to a year ago and continue to be negatively impacted by the cumulative impact from the difficult economy that began towards the end of September 2008. As Gary mentioned, the quarter was positively impacted, two percentage points from favorable foreign exchange rate comparisons.Pretax earnings were up 1%, and net earnings and diluted earnings per share were both up 5%. As you read in our press release this morning, the current quarter benefited from the favorable tax item. Excluding this tax item, net earnings grew 1% and diluted earnings per share increased 2%. Fiscal year-to-date, we have spent about $152 million to purchase over 3.5 million ADP shares in our commitment to returning excess cash to our shareholders. We are on track to return at least 300 million to 400 million of excess cash to our shareholders through share repurchases -- Now let's turn to Slide 5. In Employer Services, total revenues declined 2% for the quarter. This was still a tough comparison versus a year ago when ES [Employer Services] grew revenue of 6%. Revenue in our Payroll and Tax Filing business in the United States declined 7% in the quarter from lower new business sales during fiscal 2009 compared with the year earlier, lower client fund balances from slower sales, lower wage growth, fewer employees on our clients' payrolls and lower client retention. But beyond Payroll, revenues in the U.S. continue to grow, with 3% growth in the quarter coming from our ASO program benefit solution and 401(k), which benefited from an increase in assets from the list in the Dow.ES' pretax margin declined 10 basis points. The impact from lower revenues more than offset the benefits from last year's fourth quarter restructuring and continued expense control. These lower revenues included a decline in high margin interest passed [ph] back revenues as a result of the decline in client fund average balances.Pays per control, our same-store sales employment metric was down 5% year-over-year, which is better than we anticipated. The pace of decline lessened in our client revenue retention metric, which declined 0.1% compared to last year. But keep in mind that the key retention period is the third fiscal quarter. Gary took you through the sales results a moment ago, so let's move on to the quarter's results for PEO and turn to Slide 6.The PEO reported 9% revenue growth for the quarter, and this growth was due to increased benefits pass-through revenues that resulted from increases in both benefit rates and the number of worksite employees. Pretax margin declined slightly as the benefits from last year's restructuring and continued expense control were offset by higher pass-through revenues. Year-over-year for the second quarter, average worksite employees paid increased 4% to early 200,000. Now let's turn to Slide 7. In Dealer Services, revenues declined as anticipated, 5% for the quarter, 8% organic and continue to be negatively impacted by the cumulative effect of dealership closings and lower transactional revenues year-over-year. It has also declined in our software license fee revenues, which is recognized upon installation on our International business due to several new businesses installations in last year's second quarter.  Dealer's pretax margin improved 60 basis points due to lower headcount from the expense actions taken in last year's fourth fiscal quarter, as well as the cost control measures that we have put in place. Dealer Services competed very well in the markets it serves and continue to increase its share of consolidating market.Now let's turn to Slide 8. The schedule shows the overall impact of the client funds portfolio extended investment strategy. At the top of the slide, you see the breakdown of both the average balances and the average interest yields in orange for the short extended and long portfolio component, which corresponds to the pretax P&L impact on the bottom of the slide, with the total representing the interest on funds held for client P&L revenue line item. Before I take you through the quarter's results of the strategy, I'd like to remind everyone that the decline in market interest rates accelerated back in October 2008. As a result, the year-over-year decline in the P&L from lower rate will increase as the fiscal year progress. With that in mind, I'll take you through the quarterly results and then I'll take you through the full-year forecast on the next slide.Near the top right of the slide, you can see that the average client fund balances were down $0.7 billion compared with the year-ago period. The cumulative impact of fewer pays, client losses and slower sales compared with the year ago all contributed to the decline in average client fund balances and more than offset the positive impact of Canadian foreign exchange rates during the quarter. Staying in the orange section, in addition to the decline in average client fund balances, the average yield on the client funds portfolio declined 40 basis points or 3.8% this quarter, resulting in an overall decline of $20 million in interest on funds for client on the P&L. The impact from lower new purchase rates was most pronounced in the client short portfolio, where the average yield earned was 170 basis points lower than last year due to the decline in short-term interest rates.Looking at the blue section on the slide, average borrowings were down this quarter and the average interest rate paid on those borrowings dropped about 60 basis points to a blended average borrowing rate of 0.2%. The result was a $5 million reduction in interest expense. So when you take into consideration the entire extended strategy presented here, the results was a $21 million pretax decrease or a decline of about 12%.Now let's turn to Slide 9, where I will take you through the extended investment strategy forecast for fiscal '10. We anticipate a decline in average client fund balances of 4% to 5% resulting from pressures on the level of new business sales, continued pressures on wage growth, as well as the cumulative impact of the decline in the number of employees on our clients' payrolls and client losses. We are seeing lift in balances from SUI [State Unemployment Insurance] tax rate. However, the level of bonus payments are still unclear and we won't see these results until they are paced out over our third quarter, which is the first calendar quarter. We are anticipating a yield on the client funds portfolio of about 3.7%, down 30 to 40 basis points from fiscal 2009 compared with our prior forecast of down approximately 30 basis points due to a decline in markets interest rates across the yield curve.It's important to keep mind about 20% of the extended and long investments are subject to reinvestment risk each year, which is expected to contribute to a decline of about $75 million from client funds interest revenues, which is in line with our previous forecast. We are anticipating that average corporate extended balances will decline about $200 million. The average yield on the corporate extended investments is expected to be down 10 basis points. We anticipate average borrowings will decline about 200 million as the average interest rate paid on those borrowings is expected to be down about 90 basis points to a blended average borrowing rate of 0.2%. Taking into consideration the overall extended investment strategy, including lower borrowing costs, we anticipate a $65 million to $70 million decline in pretax earnings in fiscal 2010.Before I turn it back to Gary, I want to point out the reserve fund update from this morning's release. Last week, ADP received $14.8 million pretax or $0.02 per share, which will be recorded in the third fiscal quarter. Including this distribution, ADP has received about 99% of its original investment in the reserve fund, which leaves approximately $3 million of the original investment unrecovered. As a reminder, last year, we recorded an $18 million loss on our investment in the reserve fund. Now I'll turn it back to Gary to take you through the remainder of the forecast for fiscal 2010.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. We're now on Slide 10. We are still a little cautious about the remainder of fiscal 2010. But with more visibility on our key metrics and easing comparisons expected over the next two quarters, we are slightly improving our fiscal 2010 o
componenttext: Thank you, Chris. We're now on Slide 10. We are still a little cautious about the remainder of fiscal 2010. But with more visibility on our key metrics and easing comparisons expected over the next two quarters, we are slightly improving our fiscal 2010 outlook. So for fiscal '10, we now anticipate total ADP revenues will be flat to slightly down, and we anticipate achieving the high end of our diluted EPS from continuing operations forecast of $2.34 to $2.39. This compares with the $2.39 in fiscal '09, and both years exclude favorable income tax item.The fiscal '10 forecast also includes $14.8 million pretax or about $0.02 per share from the sixth distribution of the primary fund of the reserve fund, and Chris mentioned earlier, we received on January 29, 2010. As is our normal practice, no further share buybacks are reflected in the forecast, though it is clearly our intent to continue to return excess cash to our shareholders, again, depending upon market conditions. For our reportable segments, we anticipate that ES, Employer Services, revenues to decline about 1%, which reflects a decline in pays per control of about 4% on average for the year and flat to down one percentage point in client revenue retention.We continue to anticipate that the year-over-year comparison for pays per control will ease during the second half of fiscal 2010 compared to the second half of fiscal 2009 when this very important metric declined significantly. We anticipate high single-digit revenue growth in the PEO, and we continue to expect a decline in Dealer Services revenues of roughly minus 3% to 6%. As you heard me say earlier, we now anticipate slight to slightly higher ES and PEO worldwide new business sales growth compared with our previous forecast for sales dollars to be flat with fiscal 2009. And we continue to anticipate no improvement in our segment pretax margins.If you turn with me now to Slide 11, I'd like to leave you with some closing remarks before we open it up to your questions. While most economists believe that the U.S. economy has bottomed, we remain cautious. I believe appropriately so about the near-term outlook. The remaining six months of '10 will be challenging. The economy is recovering. It is a matter of timing and we are focused on the right things for the long term, including, most importantly, accelerating new business sales growth by investing now in our sales team and in the solutions that our clients want and need to be successful in their businesses. We are continuing to incrementally invest in Client Services, which is critical to our continued success and to maintaining our market leadership position. Our business model remain solidly intact with highly recurring revenues, client life cycles of just under 10 years and very strong cash flows. I remain committed to returning excess cash to our shareholders, including ongoing share repurchases, again, depending on market conditions. You've heard me say previously and it's worth repeating now, ADP is focused on the future and as a result, is well positioned to leverage the inevitable recovery in the economy. Now I'll turn it back to the operator and we'd be delighted to take your questions.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question is from Tim Willi with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question is from Tim Willi with Wells Fargo.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned some of the metrics that came across a little bit better than you had expected. I can't remember if you elaborated and highlighted those specifically in your comments. But if not, could you just talk about the metrics that did seem surprise
componenttext: You mentioned some of the metrics that came across a little bit better than you had expected. I can't remember if you elaborated and highlighted those specifically in your comments. But if not, could you just talk about the metrics that did seem surprise you a little bit more?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The couple that surprised us was pays was a little bit better than we expected, and that's reflected in us taking that down from our previous guidance. So it's down now to about a 4% decline over the year. Certainly, a lot of grounds cover in the second h
componenttext: The couple that surprised us was pays was a little bit better than we expected, and that's reflected in us taking that down from our previous guidance. So it's down now to about a 4% decline over the year. Certainly, a lot of grounds cover in the second half where we would hope to see the year-over-year situation improve. But based on what we've seen in the first half, that was better than what we expected. But I think as Gary went into in his remarks, the sales was a little bit better, particularly in certain parts of our business. We mentioned the small business area where we had headcount reductions last year and still grew in sales. So that was a little bit better and is reflected on the springing up of the guidance to flat to slightly up compared to our previous guidance.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the small business and your sales success, in a macro level, there still seems to be a lot of crosswinds about the health of the small business market tied into the availability of credit from the regional and community banks. I guess I'll just be curi
componenttext: In the small business and your sales success, in a macro level, there still seems to be a lot of crosswinds about the health of the small business market tied into the availability of credit from the regional and community banks. I guess I'll just be curious if your thoughts as to what portion of better sales environment that you've seen internally you would attribute to execution of your salesforce, and if you think you've tweaked there. I would imagine that's part of it. But then just also any sort of end market shifts that you saw during the quarter in terms of small businesses feeling a little bit more confident about where they're at economically, or credit availability, if there's anything there that you think also contributed to better results.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Gary. We obviously don't have access to small businesses, the credit applications or credit availability. I would tell you though that our small business salesforce feels very good right now. People are buying again both in terms of new startups a
componenttext: This is Gary. We obviously don't have access to small businesses, the credit applications or credit availability. I would tell you though that our small business salesforce feels very good right now. People are buying again both in terms of new startups as well as existing businesses. I think it wouldn't surprise me to see more buoyancy in the job reports on the low end of the marketplace for both the DLS and the ADP numbers, which will come out tomorrow. But in generally, the environment on the small end has been, both anecdotally as well as data-wise, then much more positive for us over the last number of months. And in fact, in terms of sales results, they are the most favorable of all of the results we have. So again, it feels pretty good. And we're starting to see an abatement in terms of price concessions and out of businesses on the loss business side, which also feels pretty good. So in general, I'm pretty optimistic that we are at the bottom and starting to see the early stages of a recovery on the small end of the market.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question is from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get more details on your comment about investing in future growth. Could you sort of outline maybe from a -- try to quantify what do you intend to do in various different data, such as adding sales people, product investments, Europe and so on
componenttext: I wanted to get more details on your comment about investing in future growth. Could you sort of outline maybe from a -- try to quantify what do you intend to do in various different data, such as adding sales people, product investments, Europe and so on?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Forgetting the last 18 months, two years, in the traditional ADP model, we would be striving to grow new business bookings by 8%, 10%, 11% each and every year in order to grow the business long term. In order to do that, we would normally be hiring
componenttext: Sure. Forgetting the last 18 months, two years, in the traditional ADP model, we would be striving to grow new business bookings by 8%, 10%, 11% each and every year in order to grow the business long term. In order to do that, we would normally be hiring 6% to 7% increases in headcount and then push for new products and productivity improvement to get from 6% to 7% headcount to 8%, 9%, 10% sales growth. So in essence, we think it's time to turn back to the traditional model. So as we look six months out towards fiscal '11, we're going to basically start hiring now that 6% or 7% headcount growth so that we've got people in the territory, people in telesales trained up to speed and hopefully, generating new sales straight out of the box as we move into fiscal '11 as opposed to waiting to 60 days out because, a, we've got better results and plans and we sensed an improvement in the economy, so we're basically trying to improve our distribution by staffing now.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: One question on the regulatory front. Obviously, stimulus there's stimulus to create jobs, that's a good thing. But if it includes changes to payroll taxes, that may not be necessarily be great. So could you provide some thoughts about how you think about
componenttext: One question on the regulatory front. Obviously, stimulus there's stimulus to create jobs, that's a good thing. But if it includes changes to payroll taxes, that may not be necessarily be great. So could you provide some thoughts about how you think about that?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, tax credits would normally be the way that people would be incented. If you go back historically, these are R&D kind of credits or job tax credit. There are already existing job tax credits out there. And from what I've read, best cases, you had one
componenttext: Well, tax credits would normally be the way that people would be incented. If you go back historically, these are R&D kind of credits or job tax credit. There are already existing job tax credits out there. And from what I've read, best cases, you had one million or two million jobs for these tax credits, and so you're talking about 1%. So if I lose a few tax credits on 1% growth on payroll, that would be a good problem to have. So I'm all for it. I'd love to see them bringing on as fast as they can bring it.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question is from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to start with a question on the Core Payroll business year. The revenue growth there, I guess, has been down about 7% year-over-year each of the past two quarters. How do you see that trending during the second half of this fiscal year and also on
componenttext: I want to start with a question on the Core Payroll business year. The revenue growth there, I guess, has been down about 7% year-over-year each of the past two quarters. How do you see that trending during the second half of this fiscal year and also on a longer-term basis once we're out of the recession?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: It certainly becomes an easier compare in the second half of this year. So we're hoping that, that 7% is the bottom, and so the compare gets easier. I wouldn't -- we're not in the position to talk beyond this year in any specificity, but the second half o
componenttext: It certainly becomes an easier compare in the second half of this year. So we're hoping that, that 7% is the bottom, and so the compare gets easier. I wouldn't -- we're not in the position to talk beyond this year in any specificity, but the second half of this year, clearly, the compare is better.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd think for a way for you to think about that would be that, historically, again, take out the last two years, payroll and payroll tax combined have grown kind of mid-single digits. And that's driven by like 2% payroll growth, it's driven by 5% to 6% wa
componenttext: I'd think for a way for you to think about that would be that, historically, again, take out the last two years, payroll and payroll tax combined have grown kind of mid-single digits. And that's driven by like 2% payroll growth, it's driven by 5% to 6% wage growth and tax growth that comes in that. It's driven by 8% to 10% sales growth in terms of new business. Bookings was, I guess, in fiscal '06 and '07, we were growing that number in the mid-single digits. It was even higher in some quarters. So it would certainly be our objective to get back to that and with that, you need growth in pays, you need growth in balances, both of which will happen in time. And you need growth in new business sales, which is what we're trying to ramp up for now. And you need an abatement of losses, particularly in the low end of the market where we've seen the pressure on payroll and tax bail. So I think it's going to come and get back to those levels, it's just going to take a period of time for you to get there.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And regarding the key selling season, I know it will continue to play out during the March quarter here, but you've got some period of time under your belt there already. I mean, anything notable versus prior years that you've seen, or you're doing, in te
componenttext: And regarding the key selling season, I know it will continue to play out during the March quarter here, but you've got some period of time under your belt there already. I mean, anything notable versus prior years that you've seen, or you're doing, in terms of competitive behavior or successes that maybe you're seeing this year that didn't materialize as much in the past?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we had a good year operationally, which always feels good. But it was better than last year. We had minimal price increases this year, so we had less pressure from those kinds of issues. It's really too hard to forecast because the los
componenttext: Well, first of all, we had a good year operationally, which always feels good. But it was better than last year. We had minimal price increases this year, so we had less pressure from those kinds of issues. It's really too hard to forecast because the losses really occur January and early February. Some businesses look better than last year. A couple of business don't look quite as good. But in the aggregate, we think we're in pretty good shape in terms of our forecast, and hope it's even better than what we forecast, but we think it's appropriate to be conservative at this juncture until we get the real data.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We really won't know, particularly on retention, that really is a January and into February kind of thing, and we're right in the middle of that now. So our best assumption is holding that retention number of down up to 100 basis points at this point.
componenttext: We really won't know, particularly on retention, that really is a January and into February kind of thing, and we're right in the middle of that now. So our best assumption is holding that retention number of down up to 100 basis points at this point.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: It seems the payroll cards are becoming increasingly popular among employers. So can you talk a little bit about how ADP's payroll card product is positioned in this market? To what extent are these cards an opportunity or a threat? And how do the economi
componenttext: It seems the payroll cards are becoming increasingly popular among employers. So can you talk a little bit about how ADP's payroll card product is positioned in this market? To what extent are these cards an opportunity or a threat? And how do the economics compare for ADP as the payroll processor when card-based solutions are used by your customers rather than direct deposit or paper checks?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Pay cards are continuing to grow. I think, to date, I don't know the number exactly, but we have well under one million pay cards in total.
componenttext: Pay cards are continuing to grow. I think, to date, I don't know the number exactly, but we have well under one million pay cards in total.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Over 800,000 access and in another, a couple of hundred thousand at least, slowly [indiscernible].
componenttext: Yes. Over 800,000 access and in another, a couple of hundred thousand at least, slowly [indiscernible].

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So call it one million, give or take. The economics are actually better on pay cards because unless somebody totally cashes out their payroll check, if the first time they get the pay card, which generally isn't the case for people that are active users o
componenttext: So call it one million, give or take. The economics are actually better on pay cards because unless somebody totally cashes out their payroll check, if the first time they get the pay card, which generally isn't the case for people that are active users of pay cards. We actually get the benefit of the float over the course of the time that they spend the entire net payroll, plus we get transaction fees after the initial one or two transaction. So we'd be happy to see growth in pay cards, and it's continuing to grow. It's just not a bouyant kind of growth. It's a steady growth going forward.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010

componenttext: Your next question is from Julio Quinteros with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can we switch just real quickly to the margin side of the equation, and can you just walk us through if there's any way to sort of think about the basis point impact of the incremental investments that you're making? And then what other leverage would be
componenttext: Can we switch just real quickly to the margin side of the equation, and can you just walk us through if there's any way to sort of think about the basis point impact of the incremental investments that you're making? And then what other leverage would be less, I guess, in a kind of a down side scenario to protect the margins from the current flat scenario that we have?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, obviously, a number of things go into driving the margins, and one of them is the impact of the actions we're talking about, taking in terms of ramping up sales. As sales improve, you've got the commissions on the sales. So clearly, those are the
componenttext: I think, obviously, a number of things go into driving the margins, and one of them is the impact of the actions we're talking about, taking in terms of ramping up sales. As sales improve, you've got the commissions on the sales. So clearly, those are the two pressures that we would expect to see for the next period of time, which is a good pressure to have, as Gary mentioned. When we -- a lot of the actions that you take have been taken already. With the restructuring that we took last year, it was in anticipation of the kind of pressure that we would expect to see. When you think about retention down 100 basis points, we've given that metric before that that's $50 million of revenue or if it's a 100 basis points. And for every percentage of pays, it's $20 million, and we're talking about down 4% for the year. So $50 million on the revenue retention, $80 million on the pays, that's a lot of rich revenue that puts pressure on your bottom. So that's why we took the restructuring charges that we took last year and took the reductions that we did. We tried to do that in areas that didn't -- weren't client basing in the sales areas and in service, we're continuing to invest. So when you think about the investments for the second half of this year, it's the ramping of sales headcount, it's hopefully improvement in sales and the impact that has on the sales incentives, as well as continued investments in service and implementation as you get ready for those new sales. So we continue to have very tight expense controls throughout, we've taken the actions and when you put all together, that's what we come up with no improvement in margins. And you can see the margin performance to date has been okay, not to our normal 50 basis points up year-after-year, but it's all of those things that we're trying to balance while still invest in the future and be ready for the growth when the economy does turn around.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question is from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: With pays per control better planned or maybe less bad than planned at this point, this should be a positive for your margin plan for fiscal '10. So I'm wondering if the better outlook on pays per control is what's giving you the room to add to your sales
componenttext: With pays per control better planned or maybe less bad than planned at this point, this should be a positive for your margin plan for fiscal '10. So I'm wondering if the better outlook on pays per control is what's giving you the room to add to your sales force? And if that's the case, can you quantify how much you're planning to add to your salesforce and what that invest might look like?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the salesforce, you're talking 300 to 400 people as a good way for you to think about it, kind of spread across the different market segment. We're obviously trying to push growth in the mid and high-end as well, not just adding feet on the st
componenttext: In terms of the salesforce, you're talking 300 to 400 people as a good way for you to think about it, kind of spread across the different market segment. We're obviously trying to push growth in the mid and high-end as well, not just adding feet on the street to small business because that's where the bigger productivity gains that we have, and we have longer client life cycles in the mid to high end of the market. Surely, the pays per control is the highest margin we have, that balances sort of to the extent balance improved and pays per control go down less because we did budget for pays per control to shrink in the area of 5% to 6%, so to the extent that it's 4%, that's certainly a positive benefit, and certainly high margin. And we would love to see -- it's too early to tell because we don't know about bonuses and we don't know about exactly what the SUI impact state unemployment rates, but certainly with unemployment levels at the level they are, it's going to drive all the states to ratchet up the state unemployment rate in order to keep people on unemployment both in higher numbers and for longer period. So all those are good. In a personal level, I hope they don't raise taxes in Washington, but I think that's a fat chance, so it's probably going to happen. And over time, that will certainly help as well.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, Rod, you're thinking about it right. The only nuance that would have is that I think as you start seeing the performance in the small business area and some positive signs of sales, I'd like to think that we would add sales headcount growth r
componenttext: I would say, Rod, you're thinking about it right. The only nuance that would have is that I think as you start seeing the performance in the small business area and some positive signs of sales, I'd like to think that we would add sales headcount growth regardless even if we didn't have to cover off the pays going down because it's the right thing to do long term. But the fact that pays are going down, the two of them do net out and have about the same impact on the bottom as we had planned.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: On sizing and discounting activity, this is an important time of the year to sort of look at that topic again. Are you seeing a better situation with respect to discounting this year than you did last year? And if there's any sort of numbers you could put
componenttext: On sizing and discounting activity, this is an important time of the year to sort of look at that topic again. Are you seeing a better situation with respect to discounting this year than you did last year? And if there's any sort of numbers you could put to that, that would be very helpful.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of my data there is anecdotal as opposed to reported, that can't really help you in quantifying it. But certainly, from the sales force standpoint, we are seeing both an abatement in the base, pricing in the base as well as the new sales. And as I me
componenttext: Most of my data there is anecdotal as opposed to reported, that can't really help you in quantifying it. But certainly, from the sales force standpoint, we are seeing both an abatement in the base, pricing in the base as well as the new sales. And as I mentioned in my earlier comment, particularly on the low end of the market where we think the most price pressure, that's where our sales results actually at this point are most favorable in the PEO and SBS. So we're feeling pretty good. We're kind of through the cycle and back on the way up.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say it is. The timing of this is too early to tell on January just yet. But what we have seen doesn't lead us to anything other than what we had expected. Nothing to the real positive, nothing to the real negative. So it's coming in about where w
componenttext: Yes, I'd say it is. The timing of this is too early to tell on January just yet. But what we have seen doesn't lead us to anything other than what we had expected. Nothing to the real positive, nothing to the real negative. So it's coming in about where we had expected in our original plan.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there anything important that you're considering from a strategic standpoint, either with respect to taking a harder look at the cost structure or to do something beyond what is normal to drive sales growth? Is there something we can look forward to he
componenttext: Is there anything important that you're considering from a strategic standpoint, either with respect to taking a harder look at the cost structure or to do something beyond what is normal to drive sales growth? Is there something we can look forward to hearing from you on the next Analyst Day or something with respect to strategic decision?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the cost side of that, we've been pretty aggressive the last 12 to 15 months with both our span and level exercised when we took out $80 million, $90 million worth of primarily middle management overhead. And last year, we also deferred merit
componenttext: In terms of the cost side of that, we've been pretty aggressive the last 12 to 15 months with both our span and level exercised when we took out $80 million, $90 million worth of primarily middle management overhead. And last year, we also deferred merit increases for the year. So that's a pretty big number as well. So I don't see, as we look at '11, a lot of big structural kinds of cost reductions as we go into fiscal '11. That being said, we're continuing to invest pretty heavily in our new product platform for RUN and the SBS environment. We've got it rolled out now at about 80% of the sales force. The early results from workforce now are pretty darn good in the second quarter, and we expect to get even better. And we're working on some new acquisitions that will expand our product portfolio, including the accounts payable acquisition that we just announced in the last 30 days. So all of those things, I think are going to put us in good shape for sales next year. And on top of that, you got sales force expansion, that I talked about, that will take you through a pretty detailed outlook on our product platforms and how that's going to affect us in the future in the February Analyst Meeting. So we're looking forward to sharing those with you.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add on the cost structure, I think we have to look back at what's happened over the last year. And as I mentioned before, the impact of retention and pays, as I quantified before of around $130 million if it hits those ranges, then when you t
componenttext: I would just add on the cost structure, I think we have to look back at what's happened over the last year. And as I mentioned before, the impact of retention and pays, as I quantified before of around $130 million if it hits those ranges, then when you think about it, the chart that I showed on interest on client funds down $65 million to $70 million this year. And then if you think about the Dealer business, for example, on what they're going through and the drag that is on NOI is another $50 million to $60 million. That's a lot of a hurdle to overcome this year, and that's why we took the actions we did last year with the restructuring to get us back to the kinds of margins and flattish kind of EPS that we're now guiding to. So those are big actions and I think before that, we were doing a lot to take costs out of the cost structure including the off-shoring and the data center consolidation, which is ongoing and continuing. But we've been able to do a lot on the cost side just to get to the point where we're at now, and we'll continue to do that.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from James Kissane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question is from James Kissane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010

componenttext: Just to be clear, if it wasn't for the investments the in the back half, and I guess going to the first half of fiscal '11, you would be raising your expectations for fiscal '10 EPS, right?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we kind of have raised them.
componenttext: Well, we kind of have raised them.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: But I mean above the $2.39.
componenttext: But I mean above the $2.39.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we've been -- at the $2.34 to $2.39, clearly, with the pays coming down, that helps us. The Reserve Funds obviously helps us as well. But we do see the needs and they continue the desire to invest. And I don't think we're any different than some of o
componenttext: Well we've been -- at the $2.34 to $2.39, clearly, with the pays coming down, that helps us. The Reserve Funds obviously helps us as well. But we do see the needs and they continue the desire to invest. And I don't think we're any different than some of our clients that held back a little bit. Now we've continue to invest in service and products, but we'd like to ramp that even more to really prepare ourselves for future growth. So we continue to expect to do that.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was just trying to quantify it, and you guys kind are kind of dodging it. But it does seem like you're margins would be up instead of flat.
componenttext: I was just trying to quantify it, and you guys kind are kind of dodging it. But it does seem like you're margins would be up instead of flat.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I didn't think we were dodging it.
componenttext: I didn't think we were dodging it.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, any update on GlobalView, maybe the demand picture, implementations and how they're going and maybe, a target for breakeven?
componenttext: And then, any update on GlobalView, maybe the demand picture, implementations and how they're going and maybe, a target for breakeven?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Continentally, I just returned from our meeting of the month, which is our large global clients as well as our global prospects, and I couldn't have been more pleased with a, the quality of the people there in terms of level and interest, as well as the b
componenttext: Continentally, I just returned from our meeting of the month, which is our large global clients as well as our global prospects, and I couldn't have been more pleased with a, the quality of the people there in terms of level and interest, as well as the best-selling environment for prospects to have them talk to clients. And in general, our implementation service results are pretty good. Our results in GlobalView for the first six months were terrific on a percentage uplift in terms of the new bookings. But you got to remember that, that compares to -- the place practically shut down in terms of new sales for a period of time during the middle of fiscal '09. So they're back to the kind of levels that we were tracking towards before all of these started. I don't think we're going to hit breakeven in '11, but I do think we'll do it in '12. But we're going to make a lot of progress in '11 as both the revenue growth and our need for continuing investments in infrastructure abate. The two of those together will drive us towards a breakeven as we get to 2012.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we look at it right now, it's at the very end of fiscal year '11, we start approaching that breakeven. So fiscal '12 is where we would see that happening.
componenttext: Yes, as we look at it right now, it's at the very end of fiscal year '11, we start approaching that breakeven. So fiscal '12 is where we would see that happening.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of Small Business sales, is it like an end market improvement or, and this is kind of Mike and Tim's question, or is it more just market share gains on your part?
componenttext: In terms of Small Business sales, is it like an end market improvement or, and this is kind of Mike and Tim's question, or is it more just market share gains on your part?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're at a, executing well. We downsized the sales force. We obviously kept the good guys and tried not to keep the non-performers. So the cadre is more senior and more prepared. So I think we're executing better. I think our product platform is t
componenttext: I think we're at a, executing well. We downsized the sales force. We obviously kept the good guys and tried not to keep the non-performers. So the cadre is more senior and more prepared. So I think we're executing better. I think our product platform is terrific right now, this new RUN platform with realtime payroll and all the advantages that it has, the demo is terrific. And so our guys are getting a lot of lift from that. But all that being said, I think the market place is back starting to cook again, and that wasn't the case six months ago.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You'll see at the February 18 meeting, we'll talk a little bit more about RUN and workforce now. It's two exciting products for us that were well positioned as the market returns. But both of those are areas that we've invested in the past, and looks like
componenttext: You'll see at the February 18 meeting, we'll talk a little bit more about RUN and workforce now. It's two exciting products for us that were well positioned as the market returns. But both of those are areas that we've invested in the past, and looks like they are placed to really capture market growth going forward.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question is from Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions actually related to the investment of sales force. One, just on the 300 to 400 sales people, are these all feet on the street or is it part this composition telesales force? So really just -- I'm trying to get a sense for the composi
componenttext: A couple of questions actually related to the investment of sales force. One, just on the 300 to 400 sales people, are these all feet on the street or is it part this composition telesales force? So really just -- I'm trying to get a sense for the composition of the sales force if there's any meaningful change?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No real meaningful change. We'll uplift our telesales efforts again this year, a little higher percentage than our feet on the street. But in general, call it, we're going to raise telesales by 10%, 15%. I'm going to grow feet on the street by 5% or 6%, i
componenttext: No real meaningful change. We'll uplift our telesales efforts again this year, a little higher percentage than our feet on the street. But in general, call it, we're going to raise telesales by 10%, 15%. I'm going to grow feet on the street by 5% or 6%, is a good way to think about it.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in aggregate, I think you said the headcount ramp was 6% to 7% with the goal. Is it reasonable to think, I know you're not going to give guidance for now, but is it reasonable to think about your internal -- you want to get back to sort of high s
componenttext: And then in aggregate, I think you said the headcount ramp was 6% to 7% with the goal. Is it reasonable to think, I know you're not going to give guidance for now, but is it reasonable to think about your internal -- you want to get back to sort of high single-digit sales growth in fiscal '11, or is that too aggressive at this point?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a good way to think about it in terms of objective. That would be our long-term objective. So next year shouldn't be any different than our basic business model. But I think we're through it, and we're starting to come up to the other
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a good way to think about it in terms of objective. That would be our long-term objective. So next year shouldn't be any different than our basic business model. But I think we're through it, and we're starting to come up to the other side of the valley. And so the quicker -- and the most important thing to getting back to growth again is accelerating our sales growth, so we're just trying to get out in front of it. And I think you're going to see improving sales results in the second half. So we're ramping up accordingly to get ready for next year.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I sort of read through it, I guess as you went through the quarter, you got a little bit more comfortable about the pipeline activity and kind of said this is the time that sort of pushed the needle, the environment is getting stable and the s
componenttext: And then if I sort of read through it, I guess as you went through the quarter, you got a little bit more comfortable about the pipeline activity and kind of said this is the time that sort of pushed the needle, the environment is getting stable and the sales traction seems like it's there.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, to one of the earlier questions, our forecast on EPS has come up. So obviously whether it's balances or pays per control or losses abating in the quarter, this financial outlook for the year is improving. So we don't want to repeat the mistakes of 2
componenttext: Well, to one of the earlier questions, our forecast on EPS has come up. So obviously whether it's balances or pays per control or losses abating in the quarter, this financial outlook for the year is improving. So we don't want to repeat the mistakes of 2002 and 2003, and not investing our distribution and service capability. And in fact, we're picking it up in the last six months of the year to get us in the better spots of the long term as opposed to worrying about having a great fourth quarter as opposed to investing for the five-year view.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, a little bit of a bigger-picture question for you. Any thoughts on how you would manage the business going to next year if the recovery is, let's say, above normal or below normal? Would you change anything in terms of either the businesses?
componenttext: Gary, a little bit of a bigger-picture question for you. Any thoughts on how you would manage the business going to next year if the recovery is, let's say, above normal or below normal? Would you change anything in terms of either the businesses?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well whether we are flat in terms of employment, which is probably more of the case next year as opposed to historically growing 2% in terms of pays per control or whether pay growth is flat to only up maybe 4% rather than 5% or 6% or 7% in years past. Th
componenttext: Well whether we are flat in terms of employment, which is probably more of the case next year as opposed to historically growing 2% in terms of pays per control or whether pay growth is flat to only up maybe 4% rather than 5% or 6% or 7% in years past. Those are all so much better than where we are today. I can't say that we would run the railroad any differently. That, coupled with some drag in terms of interest income as we go towards the next year, are going gauge some of our ability to maybe invest as much as we'd like to. But I don't see it fundamentally changing the business model or the way we run the railroad around here.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you look at new sales that you're anticipating this year, the desire to invest in the sales force because things are getting better, does that mean next year it'll be difficult to achieve that 50-basis point margin improvement in Employer Services that
componenttext: So you look at new sales that you're anticipating this year, the desire to invest in the sales force because things are getting better, does that mean next year it'll be difficult to achieve that 50-basis point margin improvement in Employer Services that's the goal of this company?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's really too early to make that call at this point. There certainly will be pressures that you would normally see when you've got organic revenue growth of 8% or 9%, which would not happen next year. So I think it will be more difficult to do t
componenttext: I think it's really too early to make that call at this point. There certainly will be pressures that you would normally see when you've got organic revenue growth of 8% or 9%, which would not happen next year. So I think it will be more difficult to do that in the year ahead. But again, I think we've got to be careful here because I do want to make forecasts for fiscal '11. But it certainly will be better this year, but maybe not as good traditionally as what we've enjoyed.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: But as Gary said in his opening remarks, as you're investing in the sales force and ramping, you don't get a lot of productivity items right away. And that will extend next year and put pressure on the bottom line next year. And then as sales do ramp, you
componenttext: But as Gary said in his opening remarks, as you're investing in the sales force and ramping, you don't get a lot of productivity items right away. And that will extend next year and put pressure on the bottom line next year. And then as sales do ramp, you've got the pressure of sales incentives, which are short-term pressure on your bottom line. But long term, it's the best thing that can happen. So now I think you're thinking about it right.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The flow [ph] portfolio, obviously where the interest rates are, they're bound to go up or at least it seems that way at some point. Any thoughts in changing how you would manage the portfolio or is this a strategy that you'll continue regardless of what
componenttext: The flow [ph] portfolio, obviously where the interest rates are, they're bound to go up or at least it seems that way at some point. Any thoughts in changing how you would manage the portfolio or is this a strategy that you'll continue regardless of what happens to rates going forward?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things. One is that you've actually seen us take down our guidance on the performance this year on rates because of the yield curve. We tie it to the yield curve, and we give you those specifics. And I'm going to go through these in more
componenttext: Well, a couple of things. One is that you've actually seen us take down our guidance on the performance this year on rates because of the yield curve. We tie it to the yield curve, and we give you those specifics. And I'm going to go through these in more depth in the February 18 meeting, and even give you a glimpse as to what we think about next year. But the yield curve has been pretty flat, and it's not moving very much. And everything you hear from the Fed is that, that's going to be the case for a while. I think that actually shows the benefit of the strategy that we're on. There will be a drag next year, no doubt about it based on the strategy and the reinvestment of the 20% of the portfolio. But no, I think this really -- we're sitting here today with three plus percent, 3.7% kind of interest on client funds compared to what the rate in the market is right now. That's really pretty good, and it really takes the volatility out. And we think for the long-term investor, that's a very good thing. And that's what we hear from our longer-term investors that they like the fact that we took the volatility out. It's not to say that you can't tweak that strategy a little bit going forward when you see rates starting to go up, but only in a small way. We like the latitude [ph] strategy, and we like the results it's have. And I don't see us changing from that.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Jim Macdonald with First Analysis.
componenttext: Your next question is from Jim Macdonald with First Analysis.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about what it would take to get back to raising prices in the normal fashion, what you'd need to see?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about what it would take to get back to raising prices in the normal fashion, what you'd need to see?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good question. I'd like to see retention rates starting to improve and less pressure on the price side because I think our service levels are in good shape. Clearly, as you roll out new products, the ability to increase prices also goes up. But if we get
componenttext: Good question. I'd like to see retention rates starting to improve and less pressure on the price side because I think our service levels are in good shape. Clearly, as you roll out new products, the ability to increase prices also goes up. But if we get back into an environment of where pays per control is growing as opposed to shrinking, then I think you're back into the realm of being able to look at the 1% to 2% range as opposed to 0.5% to 1% kind of range. But I don't really ever seen us pushing the envelope beyond like a 1.5% to 2% price increase in the aggregate. Obviously, you increase newer clients more because in many cases, they may have gotten a slight discount as part of an incentive to come with ADP. So I think it's going to be relatively tough next year, and more of a return to the status quo, as we talk about '12.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just one more attempt to get something on the year end. On the PEO side, do you expect headcount to increase over the year-end period, maybe that's a piece of data you might already have?
componenttext: And just one more attempt to get something on the year end. On the PEO side, do you expect headcount to increase over the year-end period, maybe that's a piece of data you might already have?

componenttext: Yes, it was definitely up in the first quarter over the fourth quarter. And the second quarter was definitely up over the first quarter, I think they were up like over 200,000.

componenttext: The ones that are the most unclear to us in terms of metric is the client retention, which we talked about. So it was up to 100 basis points, pretty wide range, but it's all going to be third quarter driven. And there's nothing we see now that would take us off that, and it looks like it's so far consistent with what we expected. I think client fund balances, same kind of thing. We've seen through the midpoint this year or year-to-date, better than we expected. But bonuses are going to be very, very -- that will have a big impact on what the actual growth is. And right now, bonuses might be higher, but it may not be in cash. It might be in options or restricted stock or that kind of thing. So between the two of those, that's where the uncertainty is right now. And I guess you could say there could be some upside, but too early to tell right now.

componenttext: I had a quick question going back to Gary's comments about how spending at the high end was still cautious, is that consistent with what you've seen in prior cycles as the economy begins to color? Are there any differences that you would highlight that's maybe climbing the dynamic?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that you can compare this cycle to any of the cycles before. I do think in the last cycle, National Accounts did turn around quicker. It certainly was the first one this time to be affected. If you think back to, must be two years ago now, th
componenttext: I'm not sure that you can compare this cycle to any of the cycles before. I do think in the last cycle, National Accounts did turn around quicker. It certainly was the first one this time to be affected. If you think back to, must be two years ago now, that's where we first started to see the pressure on the sales show up. But this is a very different downturn both on the finance side, the banking side, as well as on the mainstream side. I think that CFOs like myself with National Account-sized businesses are still waiting to see where things are going. They're beginning to talk about possible investments that you would make an investment to get savings going forward. But it's still very cautious.

componenttextpreview: Yes, our acquisition pipeline is more healthy today than it was certainly a year ago. We've made more acquisitions, mostly small acquisitions in the first six months some were not material and weren't announced. And we're working on a number of other ones
componenttext: Yes, our acquisition pipeline is more healthy today than it was certainly a year ago. We've made more acquisitions, mostly small acquisitions in the first six months some were not material and weren't announced. And we're working on a number of other ones, including some in Dealer Services that make sense. Actually, pricing in Dealer Services because the pricing in the industry is actually a little bit better, particularly internationally. So I feel very much encouraged about the acquisition environment. Again, I don't want to give anybody an impression that we're doing big deals. But in terms of product extensions, both in geographic expansion, we'll continue to see good acquisition flow.

componenttext: Hi, this is David Cohen for Tien-Tsin. I wanted to ask about the accounts payable acquisition that you did. How should we be thinking about that whole space of tax finance accounting going forward? I mean, is there an opportunity for this to become sort of more strategic? Doing something whether it's something with SAP like GlobalView but for F&A or how should we be thinking about that going forward?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, what we're putting into play is what we internally call the CFO's suite. And it's basically those services that affect the financial decision maker. So they would include stand-alone tax, wage garnishment, sales tax and accounts payable. And we
componenttext: Basically, what we're putting into play is what we internally call the CFO's suite. And it's basically those services that affect the financial decision maker. So they would include stand-alone tax, wage garnishment, sales tax and accounts payable. And we were missing the accounts payable. If you go back two years ago, we had an arrangement with a company called Harbor Payments, which was acquired by another entity which changed their strategic direction, and we had to basically retrench. We still think it's a big category potentially for us. And so we bought a company that we've been in discussions with for about six to nine months, and we're in the process of expanding out the sales force. And so we'll go to market after the CFO, controllers and tax people in larger organizations to try to sell those core products into the mix. So accounts payables are a good extension of what we already do, it involves money movement, it enjoys check printing, it enjoys control and that kinds of things that we do well from a transaction processing standpoint. And typically, as the decision maker, we already have very strong relationship with it. So we think it's the natural extension, it's not huge at this juncture, but we do think longer term, it's got pretty good potential. The experience we did have with Harbor, that Gary mentioned, that showed us that we can sell it, and our clients are interested in that suite. And so the key going forward is to ramp that up and match it with tax credit services, and tax where we intend to address that part of the market. But the good news is we did have the experience where we know that our clients were interested in that product, and we saw that we can sell it.

componenttextpreview: Well GlobalView is more of a global product. We're certainly seeing better results in Europe. Sales internationally are in Europe or I guess internationally, we're slightly down in the second quarter, although they were very positive in the first quarter
componenttext: Well GlobalView is more of a global product. We're certainly seeing better results in Europe. Sales internationally are in Europe or I guess internationally, we're slightly down in the second quarter, although they were very positive in the first quarter and year-to-date, we're positive. We're continuing to add headcount there. We're continuing to expand our China acquisition. So in general, I think our position is improving there. Europe is obviously a little bit behind the economic issues that we've seen in the U.S. But fortunately, they're not as deep as what we saw in the U.S. So we think we're not quite at the bottom there yet, but we should come out of that in fiscal '11. So in general, it's positive and actually growing at a faster rate than the U.S. has been.

componenttext: And also kind of going back to some of the questions that we were kind of visiting earlier in this Q&A regarding the margin and growth, so specifically when we look at -- as you mentioned, they're being at the bottom and kind of going with this recovery. We would obviously like for this to start trickling down to the operating margin line. And as we look at sort of the varying line items there, what could you sort of tell us in terms of where you see the upside starting to happen? And how you think of the trade off in capturing this growth such as adding salespeople versus letting it slow down. Given that we're just coming down to this bottom, you've really done a very strong job in protecting this margin?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think as I said earlier, the key drags that we've experienced are in pays per control, retention, the challenges we're seeing in the Dealer business as well as in the interest on client funds. So those, as they hit us hard this year, you'll hear interes
componenttext: I think as I said earlier, the key drags that we've experienced are in pays per control, retention, the challenges we're seeing in the Dealer business as well as in the interest on client funds. So those, as they hit us hard this year, you'll hear interest on client funds that, that will continue as well into next year. And I'll go through that in the February 18 Analyst Meeting. And you can think about retention and pays yourself. Even if pays just levels off, at least you don't have that drag. The whole key to this business is the scaling that we have in our core payroll business, and getting the sales going again. And if you're adding sales at that kind of rate that we're striving for and they're a rich component core payroll, that's where you get the margin improvement. So long term, we believe this business drives 50 basis points of margin improvement. But in the short term, the challenges are growing the business, investing the business, adding to headcount and getting that sales going. And when you do that, you got the sales incentives that are hitting you hard. So there's a period of challenge before you get back to the normal run rate of 50 basis points.

componenttext: That's typically what happened historically, and that's exactly what we're seeing today. So I think that's a good sign of things to come. Actually, if you look year-to-date, we have positive sales growth without National Account during the first six months. And I expect over the next six months that, that trend will convert over to National Account as well. National Accounts is also somewhat challenged from the standpoint of you have previously booked business that due to the economic conditions was deferred. And so you have some netting, if I could use that term, of business from prior period that's coming down, which will again startup. So again, I think that we're going to pass through that point in time some time over the next six months. And as we look forward into fiscal '11, I think we're going to be back on positive growth in all segments.

componenttext: For every dealer we lose, we're adding three. Clearly, we're winning more in the mid and up market where our historical competitor would be. And for those buyers that are focused more just on price, we are losing slightly more than we're winning in the low end of the market.
