componenttext: Good morning. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to ADP's Third Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Webcast. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Ms. Elena Charles, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ms. Charles, please go ahead.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. I'm here today with Gary Butler, ADP's President and CEO; and Chris Reidy, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joining us this morning for our third quarter fiscal 2010 earnings call and webcast. A slide presentation
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. I'm here today with Gary Butler, ADP's President and CEO; and Chris Reidy, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joining us this morning for our third quarter fiscal 2010 earnings call and webcast. A slide presentation accompanies today's call and webcast, and is available for you to print from the Investor Relations homepage of our website at adp.com. Just to remind you, the quarterly history of revenue and pretax earnings for our reportable segments has been posted to the IR section of our website. These schedules have been updated to include the third quarter of fiscal 2010, as well as the restatement of the Dealer Services Commercial business to discontinued operations since the business was sold during the quarter.
During today's conference call, we will make some forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such, involve some risks and these are  discussed on Page 2 of the slide presentation and in our periodic filings with the SEC.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Gary for his opening remarks.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Elena. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for joining us. Let me begin today's call with some opening comments about our third quarter results. Then I'll turn the call over to Chris Reidy as normal to take you through the detailed results.
componenttext:
Thank you, Elena. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for joining us. Let me begin today's call with some opening comments about our third quarter results. Then I'll turn the call over to Chris Reidy as normal to take you through the detailed results. After which, I'll return to provide you with our updated forecast for fiscal 2010. And before we take your questions, I'll provide some concluding remarks.
ADP's results for the quarter were pretty much in line with our expectations. You have already read in our press release this morning that year-over-year comparisons in our key metrics did begin to ease in the second half of this fiscal year, as we had anticipated. Having said that, our results continue to be below ADP historical standard and still being negatively impacted, but to a lesser degree by the cumulative impact of the difficult economic environment over the last year and a half.
Let me now point out to you what I believe are the noteworthy items in the quarter. In Employer Services, we did continue to see increased market receptivity from companies willing to invest again in their business infrastructure. New business sales growth flattened in the quarter after six consecutive quarters of year-over-year decline. Having said that, sales were again mixed across the business units within Employer Services. Sales to larger companies in the U.S. are still lagging somewhat from a year ago, but sales to small and midsize companies are increasing and new business sales in both Europe and GlobalView are also increasing. I am becoming more encouraged. However, I'd like to remind everyone that there is a lag in the high end of the market between reported new sales and when those bookings actually turn into revenues due to the implementation periods required as you move up market to larger more complex clients. 
Additionally, as you may recall, last quarter, we did begin accelerating next year's sales force hiring to better position ADP for stronger sales growth, but this is also expected to be somewhat of a drag on earnings over the near term. So directionally, we'll take a period of time for revenues and in turn, profits to increase. But I am pleased that new business sales are moving in the right direction and that the growth of our sales team is meeting the increasing demands in the marketplace.
Let me move on to retention. You have heard from us about declining client retention levels dating back to the last quarter of fiscal '08 and continuing throughout the full year fiscal 2009. So I'm especially pleased that during this year's critical calendar year-end period, client retention levels improved 1.4 percentage points. 
ADP's revenues are still being negatively impacted by the losses of the last several quarters prior to this quarter, and we are still not yet quite back to the retention levels from several years ago. But again, the current quarter's increased retention is directionally a very positive sign. 
Our pays per control metric did decline 2.5% during the quarter, but the pace of the decline has certainly slowed. We continue to see some indications of stabilization in terms of employment levels across the U.S., and believe that the HIRE Act recently passed by Congress may provide a needed catalyst to employers that are on the cusp of making hiring decisions. And of course, ADP will assist its clients to enable them to realize the benefits from the provisions of the HIRE Act.
We also reported growth of nearly 5% in client fund balances during the quarter after reporting declines in the last five consecutive quarters. This group growth is primarily the result of higher bonus payments than we anticipated, an increase in state employment insurance rate and we also got a small lift from favorable Canadian foreign exchange rate.
Let me move on now to Dealer Services. The automotive market is obviously still under pressure, but continues its comeback with increases in U.S. car sales volume. Consumers have responded well to recent manufacture incentives, which I also believe is a positive indicator that the outlook is strengthening. Dealer Services continue to improve its North American share, with increased new business sales and strong competitive win-loss rate. 
As you may already know, GM and Chrysler have previously announced plans to reinstate a portion of the announced closed dealerships. And of course, some of those are ADP clients. We remain very comfortable that our earlier estimate of the revenue impact from these closings that we had previously shared with you will be no more than the $50 million of annualized loss revenues to Dealer Services, and will most likely be less than our estimate.
Additionally, increased consumer credit availability and pent-up demand appears to be positively impacting this marketplace. As a result, we are encouraged by the upswing in market indicators, which I believe bodes well for the future growth of the automotive marketplace. 
With that, let me turn it over to Chris to provide you the details of our results.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. We're on Slide 4. Revenue growth turned positive in the quarter, increasing 3% including a benefit of nearly two percentage points from favorable foreign exchange rates. Increased PEO pass-through revenues also co
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. We're on Slide 4. Revenue growth turned positive in the quarter, increasing 3% including a benefit of nearly two percentage points from favorable foreign exchange rates. Increased PEO pass-through revenues also contributed two percentage points of growth, but lower client fund interest reduced growth by nearly one percentage point. Pretax earnings grew 1%, also assisted nearly two percentage points by favorable FX rates. There were a lot of swings in the quarter and I'd like to take you through the larger, more impactful items. 
As you can see in the detail of other income net in the press release, we received the distribution from the reserve funds compared with the charge we recorded in last year's third quarter. The current quarter comparison also benefited from lower severance costs and favorable foreign exchange rates. Negatively impacting the year-over-year comparisons was lower interest on client funds and increased investments in service and technology platforms.
Net earnings declined slightly as a result of the higher effective tax rate in the current quarter due to a favorable IRS audit adjustment in last year's third quarter. Earnings per share from continuing operations declined 1% in the quarter. Fiscal year-to-date, we have spent nearly $280 million to purchase over 6.5 million shares of ADP stock.
You saw in our press release this morning that our cash balance was $2.1 billion at March 31, and I want to assure you that we are committed to returning excess cash to our shareholders. We are on track to return at least $400 million of excess cash to our shareholders through share repurchases for the full fiscal year. And this amount may be higher, depending on market conditions, as well as M&A activity. I don't want you to interpret that to mean we are changing our M&A strategy because we're not. We continue to look for small, close-to-the-core acquisitions, not large acquisitions that'll be dilutive over multiple years. Before I leave this slide, I'd like to review some of the expense categories with you.
You saw in this morning's release that operating expenses increased about $100 million during the quarter. More than half of this increase is from higher PEO pass-throughs and increased expense from the FX impact that I already mentioned. Additionally, bonus payouts are expected to be higher this year. We also spent more in systems development and programming during the quarter, primarily from the investments we've spoken with you about in our newest solutions, RUN and Workforce Now. Increased expenses from FX rates had an impact here as well.
Now let's turn to Slide 5. In Employer Services, total revenues grew 1% for the quarter, all organic. Revenue in our Payroll and Tax Filing business in the United States declined 3% in the quarter and our beyond favorable revenues in the U.S. continue to grow with 8% growth in the quarter. ES' pretax margin was flat with the year ago. We're seeing the benefits from last year's fourth quarter restructuring and continued expense control, and the quarter also benefited from higher client fund balances. However, the continued investments in newest solutions and the recent acquisitions that we shared with you on February at our Annual Analyst Conference pressured the pretax margin. Additionally, fewer W-2s were processed.
Decline in pays per control on a same-store sales employment metric lessened this quarter at down 2.5% year-over-year. Losses also eased as evidenced by an increase of 1.4 percentage points in our client revenue retention metric. Gary spoke with you about the sales results a moment ago, so let's move on to the quarter's results for PEO and turn to Slide 6.
The PEO reported 15% revenue growth for the quarter, all organic. This growth was due to increased pass-through revenues and an increase in the number of worksite employees. Pretax margin declined as the benefits from last year's restructuring and continued expense control were offset by the year-over-year impact of onetime items in both the current and last year's third quarter and higher pass-throughs. Year-over-year for the third quarter, average worksite employees paid increased 5% to nearly $206,000.
Now let's turn to Slide 7. Dealer Services revenues declined as anticipated 3% for the quarter, 4% organic and continue to be negatively impacted by the cumulative effect of dealership closings, lower transactional revenues year-over-year and a decline in our software license fee revenue, which is recognized upon installation on our international business. U.S. pretax margin improved to 140 basis points due to lower headcount from the expense actions taken in last year's fourth fiscal quarter, as well as the excellent cost control measures that we have put in place. Dealer Services continued to increase its share of the consolidating market.
Now let's turn to Slide 8. This schedule shows the overall impact of the client funds portfolio extended investment strategy. At the top of the slide, in orange, you see the breakdown of both the average balances and the average interest yields for the short, extended and loan portfolio components, which corresponds to the orange portion of the pretax P&L impact on the bottom of the slide. The total pretax P&L impact for this section represents the P&L revenue line item interest on funds held for clients.
Now let's take a look at the quarterly results. Near the top right of the slide, you can see that average client fund balances were up $0.8 billion compared with the year-ago period. The cumulative impact of fewer pays, client losses and slower sales was more than offset by a combination of wage growth, particularly bonuses, increased data on employment insurance rates and the positive impact of Canadian foreign exchange rates during the quarter. 
Staying in this orange section, the average yield on the client funds portfolio declined 50 basis points to 3.2% this quarter due to the seasonally high level of client funds that were invested overnight at about 15 basis points. The decrease in the average yield more than offset the growth in client balances, resulting in a decline of $16 million in interest on funds held for clients on the P&L that you see near the bottom right of the slide. The impact from lower new purchase rates was most pronounced in the client short portfolio, due to the seasonally high level of client funds invested overnight at rates which was 70 basis points lower than last year, as the decline in market interest rates has continued since last year's third quarter.
Moving on to the blue section of the slide. Average borrowings were down this quarter and the average interest rate paid on those borrowings dropped about 10 basis points to a blended average borrowing rate of 0.2%. Our third quarter is seasonally our highest client fund balance quarter, which makes it our lowest borrowing quarter. As a result, the impact in interest expense that you see near the bottom right of the slide was negligible. When you take into consideration the entire extended strategy, which also includes the corporate extended interest income shown in purple on the slide, the result was a $20 million pretax decrease or a decline of about 12%.
Now let's turn to Slide 9, where I'll take you through the extended investment strategy forecast for fiscal 2010. We anticipate a decline in average client fund balances of 1% to 2%, which is an improvement from our previous forecast of a decline of 4% to 5%, as a result of increased balances related to wage growth and state unemployment tax rates. We are anticipating a yield on the client funds portfolio of about 3.6%, down about 40 basis points from fiscal 2009 and down slightly from our prior forecast.
Client fund interest revenues are expected to decline about $70 million, which is an improvement of about $5 million compared with our previous forecast. We continue to anticipate that average corporate extended balances will decline about $200 million. The average yield on the corporate extended investments is expected to be down 20 basis points, a slight decrease in yields from our prior forecast, which partially offset the benefit of the client fund interest revenue line. 
We continue to anticipate average borrowings will decline about $200 million and the average interest rate paid on those borrowings to be down about 90 basis points, so blended average borrowing rate of 0.2%. Taking into consideration the pretax earnings impact of the overall extended investment strategy, including lower borrowing cost, we anticipate a decline of about $65 million in fiscal 2010 as you see at the bottom right of the slide.
Now I'll turn it back to Gary to take you through the remainder of the forecast for fiscal 2010.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. We're now on Slide 10. For fiscal 2010, we do anticipate total ADP revenues will be about flat with last year. And we anticipate achieving diluted EPS from continuing operations from around $2.36 to $2.38 compared with $2.38 in fiscal '0
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. We're now on Slide 10. For fiscal 2010, we do anticipate total ADP revenues will be about flat with last year. And we anticipate achieving diluted EPS from continuing operations from around $2.36 to $2.38 compared with $2.38 in fiscal '09, excluding favorable income tax item and the divested Commercial business for both fiscal year. As is our normal practice, no further share buybacks are reflected in the forecast, though it remains clearly our intent to continue to return excess cash to our shareholders, depending upon market condition.
For our reportable segments, we anticipate Employer Services revenues declining up to 1%, which reflects a decline in pays per control of about 4% on average for the full year and about flat client revenue retention. We anticipate 8% to 10% revenue growth in the PEO Services, driven by higher pass-through revenues. And we do anticipate slightly higher combined Employer Services and PEO sales worldwide for new business. We expect a decline in Dealer Services revenues of minus 3% to 4%, and we continue to anticipate no improvement in our segment pretax margin.
Turning to Slide 11. I'd like to leave you with some closing remarks before we open it up for your questions. We have seen certainly some easing in the U.S. economic landscape, and the economy appears to be on its way to recovery. Our key business metrics are improving and we are focused on the right things for the long term. We continue to invest in our direct sales team, fundamentally adding new hires to accelerate new business sales growth. As we spoke with you at our annual analyst event back in February, we are also investing in newer technology platforms and solutions, such as RUN, for our low-end market, Workforce Now, our ASO offering, GlobalView and Streamline for our international and global clients. These are all designed to meet the needs of our clients and prospects. And we are continuing to invest incrementally in client service, which is critical for our continued success and to maintaining our market leadership position. These investments will, to some degree, pressure ADP's near-term outlook but are necessary for growth over the long term. Our business model remains solidly intact with highly recurring revenues, client life cycles of just under 10 years and excellent cash flow. Our cash position, as Chris mentioned earlier, is strong at $2.1 billion and our capital requirement are very low. 
I remain committed to returning excess cash to our shareholders, including ongoing share repurchases, obviously depending upon market conditions. ADP is a great company, and we continue to execute successfully against our five-point strategic growth program that we reviewed again with you back in February at our Analyst Conference. I said previously, that ADP is well positioned to leverage the inevitable recovery in the economy and it feels like the recovery is upon us. I remain optimistic about ADP's long-term opportunities for growth.
Let me now turn it over to the operator to take your questions.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from Julio Quinteros of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from Julio Quinteros of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just real quickly on the SMB [Small Business] side, in terms of your performance there. Can you just characterize the growth of the SMB? Is it market share gains versus sort of a recovery of the SMB  segment in terms of employee growth? Any way to charact
componenttext: Just real quickly on the SMB [Small Business] side, in terms of your performance there. Can you just characterize the growth of the SMB? Is it market share gains versus sort of a recovery of the SMB  segment in terms of employee growth? Any way to characterize what you guys are seeing there?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a series of things. One is, I think we're executing extremely well in both of those segments. Secondly, I think the economy, and you see it in the National Employment Report in terms of the return of the service sector, as well small business
componenttext: I think it's a series of things. One is, I think we're executing extremely well in both of those segments. Secondly, I think the economy, and you see it in the National Employment Report in terms of the return of the service sector, as well small business in terms of employment. And thirdly, I think that our new product platforms, particularly the RUN platform and our Workforce Now are somewhat making hay in the marketplace, and it feels real good.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the longer-term impact, the things like healthcare reform, and you kind of balance that against new payroll additions. Can you just give us a sense, on when you think that actually begins to manifest itself in some impact to your business
componenttext: When you look at the longer-term impact, the things like healthcare reform, and you kind of balance that against new payroll additions. Can you just give us a sense, on when you think that actually begins to manifest itself in some impact to your business? Or I guess alternatively, is it holding back people from hiring at this point? Is there any way to sort of triangulate around healthcare reform specifically?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there were people that were apprehensive and still are. In fact, we're involved in some of the discussion in Washington today, in terms of trying to figure out exactly how the compliance and the regulation works for the new healthcare reform. Obvi
componenttext: I think there were people that were apprehensive and still are. In fact, we're involved in some of the discussion in Washington today, in terms of trying to figure out exactly how the compliance and the regulation works for the new healthcare reform. Obviously, as the biggest mover of funds to the IRS and the biggest person in the client business across the U.S., ADP will certainly play a significant role there. It's still not 100% clear on healthcare reform. But clearly, payroll and HR systems have to be the system of record for all healthcare reform. And any kind of compliance, money movement, penalties and enforcement is going to have to be administered by companies like ADP and some of the reforms will clearly require regulatory compliance and reporting, both to employees and employers and to the IRS and in some cases, even on W-2. We're also selling healthcare, as you know, and particularly in the PEO, where we're qualified to sell healthcare in multiple states and could be properly positioned as a insurance pool because we provide healthcare to multiple companies in multiple states. I think it generally will be a positive for us, but I think it's going to take a period of, really, 12 months to have that kind of come to fruition and the regulation gets published, et cetera. On top of that, I think the HIRE Act is helping us across the board, probably more upmarket and then the mid-market, the down market. But in general, regulation compliance, penalties and higher taxes, although we may not like them personally, generally help ADP as a company.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Rod Bourgeois with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question is from Rod Bourgeois with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to inquire about the selling environment. It appears that you have a pretty easy comparison in the June quarter for your sales or bookings growth. Do you anticipate your sales growth will turn substantially positive in the June quarter based
componenttext: I just wanted to inquire about the selling environment. It appears that you have a pretty easy comparison in the June quarter for your sales or bookings growth. Do you anticipate your sales growth will turn substantially positive in the June quarter based on the easy comparison and some of the progress that you've noted in the sales environment?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Is there an explanation point behind that yes?
componenttext: Great. Is there an explanation point behind that yes?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll see.
componenttext: We'll see.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you comment on fiscal '11, what a realistic sales growth goal would be? And then can you get into the sort of upper single-digit or low double-digit sales growth range in fiscal '11, particularly as you get the sales force primed before fiscal y
componenttext: Gary, can you comment on fiscal '11, what a realistic sales growth goal would be? And then can you get into the sort of upper single-digit or low double-digit sales growth range in fiscal '11, particularly as you get the sales force primed before fiscal year '11 has even started?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rod, we've said many times, over time, the ADP model is really focused on driving sales growth and driving retention. They're the two things that affect our organic growth the most. And historically, we've always strived for upper-single digit, approachin
componenttext: Rod, we've said many times, over time, the ADP model is really focused on driving sales growth and driving retention. They're the two things that affect our organic growth the most. And historically, we've always strived for upper-single digit, approaching double-digit kind of sales growth across the enterprise. And as we return to more normal times, I don't expect that to change from our historical perspective.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the two are related, Rod. How we do in the fourth quarter will set a foundation for what we would expect to happen in fiscal year '11. So the two are interdependent. And to expand a little bit on your question, we are hopeful the year-over-year co
componenttext: I think the two are related, Rod. How we do in the fourth quarter will set a foundation for what we would expect to happen in fiscal year '11. So the two are interdependent. And to expand a little bit on your question, we are hopeful the year-over-year compare in the fourth quarter is an easy compare. However, having said that, and national accounts should tend to have and our bigger clients, a bigger portion of the sales in May and June traditionally. So as we have said, we haven't seen that to begin to turnaround in that part of the market. So that's an open question of just -- even though with easy compare, it's traditionally a higher seasonal selling time in May and June. So still a lot of water to come under the bridge before we can talk too much about fiscal year '11.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess on the margin front, it seems key for the Payroll and Tax business to resume positive growth, so that you can get some scale leverage benefit on the margin front. Do you think it's feasible in fiscal '11 to get at least some scale leverage ben
componenttext: And I guess on the margin front, it seems key for the Payroll and Tax business to resume positive growth, so that you can get some scale leverage benefit on the margin front. Do you think it's feasible in fiscal '11 to get at least some scale leverage benefit given the improving economy and the possibility that Payroll and Tax business can resume positive growth again? Do you see that potentially playing out, or is it just way too early to call that at this point?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, it's too early to call any yet to be at this point and call on next year. A lot will depend on how we finish. But as we said in our remarks, we do expect there to be significant pressure on our margins next year and on our earnings. For some
componenttext: Well, again, it's too early to call any yet to be at this point and call on next year. A lot will depend on how we finish. But as we said in our remarks, we do expect there to be significant pressure on our margins next year and on our earnings. For some good reasons, if sales do begin to ramp, that's a good thing. And we want to go with that, we want to continue investing in the business. We're investing in IT technology with what you saw with RUN and Workforce Now and others. So all of those things, we're going to continue to invest, we're going to continue to ramp sales as quickly as possible. And then you have the issue of the client fund balance interest overhang, which I went through with the February meeting. And all of those things put pressure on the bottom. But they're all designed to get the payroll growth back growing again. So I think it's there for the long term.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question is from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to pick up on some of that forward-looking comments, sorry, if I could, and go back to the analyst meeting in February when you guys did make comments on the longer-term growth trajectory of the business. And I think at the time, you guys su
componenttext: I just wanted to pick up on some of that forward-looking comments, sorry, if I could, and go back to the analyst meeting in February when you guys did make comments on the longer-term growth trajectory of the business. And I think at the time, you guys suggested that the fiscal '11 revenue growth, without being specific, would be below the 6% to 8% CAGR you're targeting through fiscal '15 and that many margin expansion next year would be less than your typical 50 basis point target which sounds like what you're reinforcing here. So I guess any other EPS leverage for next year would really need to come from either interest income on your corporate cash or share buybacks, is that kind of the right read there?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Accurate as that.
componenttext: Accurate as that.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what kind of price lift is baked into those figures when you think about a revenue growth rate south of 6% to 8% next year? Is it more like kind of a flat to up 1% that we've been seeing or more like the 1% to 2% that you were more accustomed to prior
componenttext: And what kind of price lift is baked into those figures when you think about a revenue growth rate south of 6% to 8% next year? Is it more like kind of a flat to up 1% that we've been seeing or more like the 1% to 2% that you were more accustomed to prior to the downturn?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're going to be cautious on pricing next year. It's more important to us long term as a company to drive increased retention than it is to drive price increases in the near term. So I think we will get more price next year than we have for the l
componenttext: I think we're going to be cautious on pricing next year. It's more important to us long term as a company to drive increased retention than it is to drive price increases in the near term. So I think we will get more price next year than we have for the last year or two. But that being said, I think it's the time for conservatism as opposed to aggressiveness in the marketplace.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you just talk about your comfort level with the dividend payout ratio? I mean, obviously, earnings growth should be better over the next couple of years. Should investors expect dividend to just keep pace with the earnings growth or is there
componenttext: And then can you just talk about your comfort level with the dividend payout ratio? I mean, obviously, earnings growth should be better over the next couple of years. Should investors expect dividend to just keep pace with the earnings growth or is there a possibility for the payout ratio to increase? Obviously, you've got some other cash deployment priorities with potential M&A and...

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You have to remember that dividend payouts are board decisions, not CEO and CFO decisions. So it's really easy for us to be comfortable since we don't make the decisions. But in terms of the recommendations, I don't see any real changes to our go-forward
componenttext: You have to remember that dividend payouts are board decisions, not CEO and CFO decisions. So it's really easy for us to be comfortable since we don't make the decisions. But in terms of the recommendations, I don't see any real changes to our go-forward policy as contrasted to our more recent policies of the past.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have said that we're happy with the dividend payout ratio, where it is, and that would imply that the dividends would go up with earnings growth. But again, that's subject to board approval and that position hasn't changed.
componenttext: Yes, we have said that we're happy with the dividend payout ratio, where it is, and that would imply that the dividends would go up with earnings growth. But again, that's subject to board approval and that position hasn't changed.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the ASO market, kind of the mid-market HR BPO stuff, I mean, how big of a business is that for you guys today? I know you've been highlighting it in the past as one of your key potential longer-term growth opportunities. But can you help us size it a b
componenttext: On the ASO market, kind of the mid-market HR BPO stuff, I mean, how big of a business is that for you guys today? I know you've been highlighting it in the past as one of your key potential longer-term growth opportunities. But can you help us size it a bit currently and how fast it's growing?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the COS business, which is just a different name for ASO up market, is a $150 million kind of business with very nice growth estimates. The low-end of the market in the SBS space, the ASO we have there is today certainly less than a $50 million busi
componenttext: Well, the COS business, which is just a different name for ASO up market, is a $150 million kind of business with very nice growth estimates. The low-end of the market in the SBS space, the ASO we have there is today certainly less than a $50 million business. And we just really launched the ASO business in the mid-market last fiscal. So it's relatively nascent with great growth rates obviously off of a small number. But these businesses, all three, are multi-hundred million dollar businesses for ADP in the planning horizon. So we have great plans and great expectations for all three segments with the ASO model.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Jim Macdonald with First Analysis.
componenttext: Your next question is from Jim Macdonald with First Analysis.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Beyond payroll took a nice tick up this quarter. Could you talk a little bit more on what caused that?
componenttext: Beyond payroll took a nice tick up this quarter. Could you talk a little bit more on what caused that?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think there was anything specifically. You have to remember that particularly in mid-market where we have our highest penetration of beyond payroll, that Workforce Now which includes our benefits offering, our time and labor modules and our HR ben
componenttext: I don't think there was anything specifically. You have to remember that particularly in mid-market where we have our highest penetration of beyond payroll, that Workforce Now which includes our benefits offering, our time and labor modules and our HR benefits kind of businesses, all of those are doing very well because majors is doing extremely well both in terms of the product with Workforce Now, but as a business unit in terms of new sales. So I guess it would be primarily there, plus we're doing very well particularly selling workers comp and 401(k) into the base on the small end which would drive that. Our workers comp penetration is way up year-to-year, and so I suspect that's doing it as well.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. It's pretty much across the board. No one particular item driving it. But it extends to COBRA and Taxware and VirtualEdge, which we have the Screening and Selection business, all the HR kind of businesses that Gary mentioned. So it's pretty mu
componenttext: Yes, it is. It's pretty much across the board. No one particular item driving it. But it extends to COBRA and Taxware and VirtualEdge, which we have the Screening and Selection business, all the HR kind of businesses that Gary mentioned. So it's pretty much across the board.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you expect -- where can that growth rate get to in beyond payroll do you think?
componenttext: Do you expect -- where can that growth rate get to in beyond payroll do you think?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we're striving to grow sales as I described earlier. Historically, we've always been able to grow sales for our beyond payroll at a faster pace than fewer payroll. So the blended average, you pick the number in terms of going forward grow
componenttext: Well, certainly, we're striving to grow sales as I described earlier. Historically, we've always been able to grow sales for our beyond payroll at a faster pace than fewer payroll. So the blended average, you pick the number in terms of going forward growth, it's going to be a little lower for payroll and a little higher for beyond payroll. So it certainly is capable of getting back to the double-digit.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Which is true if you look back over the last couple of years, it was double-digits comparison.
componenttext: Which is true if you look back over the last couple of years, it was double-digits comparison.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You had four small acquisitions. Anything strategic you want to talk about there?
componenttext: You had four small acquisitions. Anything strategic you want to talk about there?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we mentioned earlier our Accounts Payable business, which we're pretty excited about. And we bought a new Internet HR platform for primarily the U.K. market, although we think it has legs beyond the U.K. market. And we had a couple of other kind of
componenttext: Well, we mentioned earlier our Accounts Payable business, which we're pretty excited about. And we bought a new Internet HR platform for primarily the U.K. market, although we think it has legs beyond the U.K. market. And we had a couple of other kind of roll-up kinds of acquisitions. But those would be the two that come first to mind.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, those are the main ones. And if you look back at our February analyst meeting, we went through most of those.
componenttext: Yes, those are the main ones. And if you look back at our February analyst meeting, we went through most of those.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from David Grossman with Thomas Weisel.
componenttext: Your next question is from David Grossman with Thomas Weisel.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary and Chris, you've done a great job of kind of laying out, at least in your term, kind of the impact of a lot of different things that you're doing and in terms of what impact that will have on profitability. Can you help us understand how much of thi
componenttext: Gary and Chris, you've done a great job of kind of laying out, at least in your term, kind of the impact of a lot of different things that you're doing and in terms of what impact that will have on profitability. Can you help us understand how much of this is just you reminding us of a typical ADP cycle coming out of the downturn with suppressed revenue and the need to continue to reinvest in the business? And how much of this maybe things that have changed in the marketplace that you want to either take advantage of or you need to respond to?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there is a little bit of that. You want to make sure that you're still investing throughout because the business model is a great business model. So you don't want to do some of what we talked about in the past having done out of the last downturn
componenttext: I think there is a little bit of that. You want to make sure that you're still investing throughout because the business model is a great business model. So you don't want to do some of what we talked about in the past having done out of the last downturn, which is tightening the belt a little too much. And you'll recall Gary talking about several years ago, getting the battle of the ship up. We want to make sure that the battle of the ship stays up so we continue to do that. Now having said that, we have some great opportunities in the market with RUN introduction and the Workforce Now introduction, which I think captures an opportunity in the market. So we want to make sure we continue to invest in that area.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think it's basically the three things that you really have to take in consideration as you think about your modeling for next year. One is, for sure, interest income is going to go down next year and we've tried to lay that out for you as m
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think it's basically the three things that you really have to take in consideration as you think about your modeling for next year. One is, for sure, interest income is going to go down next year and we've tried to lay that out for you as much as we can without getting into the forecasting game. Secondly, we are investing in the business, and particularly in sales and new technology and for the future of the business. I want to continue to do that because it's the right thing to do long term. And even as we recover in the new sales category, it does take some period of time for sales to turn to revenue. And ultimately, that's what drives organic growth and scale margin contribution. And so it's a little bit about timing. And I think what you've seen in previous down cycles like we saw in '02 and '03, it probably won't be all that different this time as we come out of the valley and start going back up the mountain on the other side.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we've said when we go through the waterfall chart, the key to growth in this business is that differential between the revenue driven by sales and what you lose on the retention and the revenues you don't retain. It's much less impacted, as you know, b
componenttext: As we've said when we go through the waterfall chart, the key to growth in this business is that differential between the revenue driven by sales and what you lose on the retention and the revenues you don't retain. It's much less impacted, as you know, by the pays per control and the client-fund balance, everything. All that is nice. But the real differential is getting that sales engine moving again and generating the revenue, and then doing everything it can to stop losses and to improve retention. And that's where you get the bulk of the growth going forward.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if you just look at the new sales as a standalone and that downward impact to commissions, does it typically take a full 12-month period to kind of get out of that downward pressure from the commissions. Is that a good way to think about that headwind
componenttext: And if you just look at the new sales as a standalone and that downward impact to commissions, does it typically take a full 12-month period to kind of get out of that downward pressure from the commissions. Is that a good way to think about that headwind in particular?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair.
componenttext: I think that's fair.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one last thing on the balances, I think you said that you got an unemployment benefit during the period. Is that something that is sustained? Is that an ongoing benefit that goes on for the next three or four quarters?
componenttext: And then just one last thing on the balances, I think you said that you got an unemployment benefit during the period. Is that something that is sustained? Is that an ongoing benefit that goes on for the next three or four quarters?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's recurring, but you don't get the growth again. I know you've kind of got to grow over that next year. So it'll be there. But you won't be growing the same amounts from that item.
componenttext: It's recurring, but you don't get the growth again. I know you've kind of got to grow over that next year. So it'll be there. But you won't be growing the same amounts from that item.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've got to remember there are three or four things that affect balances. The primary thing is adding new clients, which we're highly focused on. Secondly is higher wages to employees. You're seeing that now in the form of bonuses, and I think even thou
componenttext: You've got to remember there are three or four things that affect balances. The primary thing is adding new clients, which we're highly focused on. Secondly is higher wages to employees. You're seeing that now in the form of bonuses, and I think even though we don't see the data, what's happening in the general economy would indicate that people working more hours, people are starting to be hired. So we are seeing wage growth as well as internal employee growth in certain companies. On top of that, unemployment taxes are going to be up for a while because they typically lag a year on the way down, and they will continue to lag a year beyond on the way up because the states have to fill their coffers to pay for all this 10% on employment tax. And then on top of that, you're going to see higher taxes that will come out beyond that. So again, the one thing that we can control as a company is selling more payroll accounts as well as making sure that most of them use our tax filing and direct deposit services. So we're highly focused on that. But I think the trends are certainly at our back, we would hope, as opposed to in our face at this point in time.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Michael Baker with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question is from Michael Baker with Raymond James.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary gave a good color in terms of what was going on from the sales perspective in terms of large, mid-sized and small employers. I was wondering if you could do a similar dynamic around pays or hiring, just kind of what you're seeing or your sense as it
componenttext: Gary gave a good color in terms of what was going on from the sales perspective in terms of large, mid-sized and small employers. I was wondering if you could do a similar dynamic around pays or hiring, just kind of what you're seeing or your sense as it stacks up on a relative basis.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen our pays per control really start to flatten. But you have to remember that even though we're down 2 1/2% pays per control this quarter, that's on top, I think, than the same quarter last year of around down 3 1/2% or 4%. So we're still
componenttext: Well, we have seen our pays per control really start to flatten. But you have to remember that even though we're down 2 1/2% pays per control this quarter, that's on top, I think, than the same quarter last year of around down 3 1/2% or 4%. So we're still down on a two-year basis, almost 6% in pays per control. And so that's starting to flatten. It will still take another, call it, two, three maybe even four quarters before we get through that and get to a real flat to positive growth kind of area. Another statistic is not something that we really published is, we have a Screening and Selection business which has, I think, around 10,000, 15,000 clients, mostly in the mid and up market. And we're seeing the selection, the screening process is up in recent months 20% to 30% over prior periods. So that's a pretty good indication within our base, although not statistically fully accurate, it's more anecdotal. But clearly, people are starting to hire again. I think you see the balance increases that are indicative around increased hiring and bonuses. And certainly, the National Employment Report is getting closed to push in terms paid growth with positives in the service sector and the low end of the market. So again, I think all of the signs are good but it's pretty easy to be good compared to how bad it's been for a period of time. So I think this thing is through the bottom and going to start to ease up, but I think we have to be cautious, do not get ramp in enthusiasm as we go through this cycle because it's going to be a gradual upswing and it passed its prologue, it will take some period of time before we really start to see the benefit.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you look at what we've said in our guidance, that we would be around 4% down for the full year. Just to put that in perspective, as Gary began to -- it's 4.6% year-to-date, that was 6 1/2% down in the first quarter, 5% down in the second quarter, now 2
componenttext: As you look at what we've said in our guidance, that we would be around 4% down for the full year. Just to put that in perspective, as Gary began to -- it's 4.6% year-to-date, that was 6 1/2% down in the first quarter, 5% down in the second quarter, now 2 1/2%. So it's going in the right direction, but 4% for the year would imply very close to zero on the fourth quarter. So you can kind of see that it's leveling off, look forward to the days where that's going positive, but it will take awhile to get there and it's a gradual kind of thing. But our guidance for this year would be about 4% down, when all is said and done.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to help you guys think about it a little bit is that, last downcycle as we came through the recession of '01, '02, and pulled out in '03 and '04. It actually took 10 quarters before we went from negative or near flat kind of growth to a positive pace
componenttext: Just to help you guys think about it a little bit is that, last downcycle as we came through the recession of '01, '02, and pulled out in '03 and '04. It actually took 10 quarters before we went from negative or near flat kind of growth to a positive pace for controlled growth, because it just the way the cycle works, because people will go to more hours and more hours of overtime, add more temporary staff before they start putting permanent people on the payroll. And so we just have to gauge our expectations here a little bit as we think about that.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But it's also worth putting that in perspective. Because going through a period where it's down 6% a quarter, 5% a quarter, pays per control becomes very prominent. But now that unemployment rates have reached a very high level, any improvement from that
componenttext: But it's also worth putting that in perspective. Because going through a period where it's down 6% a quarter, 5% a quarter, pays per control becomes very prominent. But now that unemployment rates have reached a very high level, any improvement from that 1%, I'll remind you, is only worth about $20 million of revenue to us. So there's a lot of focus on that metric. But the reality going forward is, it's driving sales in excess of the losses from retention. And if we get flat employment levels for a while, you're basically forgoing a traditional 1% to 2% or $20 million to $40 million. It's not that big a deal now that the bulk of the decline in pays is behind us. And I think that's sometimes misunderstood. That's more important going forward, and it really isn't as impactful as the differential in sales and retention.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up, which employer segment would you anticipate improving the quickest, large, mid or small?
componenttext: And just a follow-up, which employer segment would you anticipate improving the quickest, large, mid or small?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've seen it in the past, but it's led by small. But it's not clear that that's evidence that that's the way it will recover this time. But that's where it did last time.
componenttext: We've seen it in the past, but it's led by small. But it's not clear that that's evidence that that's the way it will recover this time. But that's where it did last time.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The shrinkage that we've seen in pays per control is not dramatically different by segment. I mean, it's different, but not anything that I would run to my PC and change my model on. In the previous recession, we saw a much deeper dive at the high end of
componenttext: The shrinkage that we've seen in pays per control is not dramatically different by segment. I mean, it's different, but not anything that I would run to my PC and change my model on. In the previous recession, we saw a much deeper dive at the high end of the market which we didn't see this time. So I think it's pretty much back to Chris's comments. It's all about selling new clients and keeping the ones we have and growing the business.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at the Small Business segment and you take a look PEO, obviously, we have a pretty good sense of how that's growing with what you provide. I was wondering how the ASO plus agency option is shaping up. Is it opening up a new market for you? Are
componenttext: If you look at the Small Business segment and you take a look PEO, obviously, we have a pretty good sense of how that's growing with what you provide. I was wondering how the ASO plus agency option is shaping up. Is it opening up a new market for you? Are those that would not really consider PEO? Or are you seeing maybe a little bit of cannibalization on the PEO side?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That was obviously one of our strategic concerns because we've been highly successful in the PEO, arguably the best in the industry. And so we clearly see the need for the ASO platform, but we're also concerned about left pocket and right pocket in terms
componenttext: That was obviously one of our strategic concerns because we've been highly successful in the PEO, arguably the best in the industry. And so we clearly see the need for the ASO platform, but we're also concerned about left pocket and right pocket in terms of the sale scene. So far, we haven't seen any degradation in PEO sale based upon move to ASO. But we've been kind of careful about how we do that. We are pretty stringent on our underwriting criteria in the PEO more towards a white-collar, grey-collar kind of environment. And the ASO clearly opens up the category for people who don't need our underwriting requirements in the PEO as a natural candidate for the ASO operation or product set. So I think we've got it pretty much in hand, and I don't expect any significant drag on the PEO at least near term.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question is from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question is from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Nathan Rozof on for Adam Frisch. I wanted to turn briefly to changes you're seeing coming out of Washington, specifically. Can you provide us any insight into your strategy to capture some of the opportunity from the recent healthcare reform bill?
componenttext: This is Nathan Rozof on for Adam Frisch. I wanted to turn briefly to changes you're seeing coming out of Washington, specifically. Can you provide us any insight into your strategy to capture some of the opportunity from the recent healthcare reform bill?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you have to wait until the regulations are finalized. As I mentioned previously, the system of record for all of these kinds of compliance and money movement and penalties and enforcement has to either the payroll system or the HR benefit system, bo
componenttext: Well, you have to wait until the regulations are finalized. As I mentioned previously, the system of record for all of these kinds of compliance and money movement and penalties and enforcement has to either the payroll system or the HR benefit system, both of which arguably we are market leaders in both categories. And as the largest mover of funds and compliance to the IRS kind of by default, we think we've got to be one of the go-to-guys here, so to speak, in terms of enforcement. We also sell healthcare, and it clearly will drive more employers and employees to healthcare options. So we think it's clearly going to help us there. Secondly, the PEO is already a qualified health provider as a co-employer in 30 states or whatever the number is, something like that. So we think we're going to be well-positioned in terms of leads to the PEO for people who now want to offer healthcare. And in terms of reporting, a lot of it in the early reviews are going to have to be done either through employer reporting or W2 reporting in terms of the individual compliance and what happens to be there. We've also seen this respond very aggressively on the opportunity on the HIRE Act in the media as well as in some of our advertising. And I certainly think that's helping us in the marketplace. So clearly, we've got more definitive strategies to work on as these legs get finalized. And we'll try to be a little bit clearer on that as we go into fiscal '11 to kind of help you plan for the years ahead.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to turn just briefly over to the Dealer Services segment. Can you provide any additional color on what's driving the improvement in new sales? Where is demand improving? Where does it remain soft? And how does the pricing environment look specifi
componenttext: I wanted to turn just briefly over to the Dealer Services segment. Can you provide any additional color on what's driving the improvement in new sales? Where is demand improving? Where does it remain soft? And how does the pricing environment look specific to dealer?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I think we've made tremendous strides as a company to being the global provider for the OEM. And so our partnerships with the manufacturers has never been better, both in terms of the U.S. as well as Europe and the Far East. So I think
componenttext: Well, first of all, I think we've made tremendous strides as a company to being the global provider for the OEM. And so our partnerships with the manufacturers has never been better, both in terms of the U.S. as well as Europe and the Far East. So I think that's number one. Number two is, I think we've done an excellent job in expanding the breadth of our product offering and keeping it current from a technology standpoint. A good example of that would be at the recent NADA, we released all the mobile platforms for all of our applications where service writers can write up service orders and do inquiries straight from a PDA or any of the mobile platforms that we may have. And pricing wise, it's certainly more competitive than it's been. But the bigger bundle of applications is also helping us from that standpoint. And we have seen a lessening of losses, of job applications in our businesses over the last number of months. So I would expect that our market share gains to continue along the same pace as they've been for the last year as we look through the year ahead.

componenttext: This is Giri for Kelly. Just had a couple of quick questions. One, I'm not sure if you updated us before, could you tell us about National Accounts and what you're seeing this quarter versus what you saw just last quarter? And if you see things changing noticeably there?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: And any thoughts on Europe and what you're seeing in Europe versus the U.S. in terms of trends?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The environment in Europe is certainly tougher than, say, it was a year, a year and a half ago. Although, our sales results are still positive in Europe and the shrinkage is not nearly as dramatic because the social laws and the regulations are much more
componenttext: The environment in Europe is certainly tougher than, say, it was a year, a year and a half ago. Although, our sales results are still positive in Europe and the shrinkage is not nearly as dramatic because the social laws and the regulations are much more stringent in Europe than they are in the U.S. And we're continuing to have great success with our GlobalView and Streamline offerings in Europe and I expect that to continue.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: Your next question is from Gary Bisbee with Barclays Capital.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I understand you're not giving guidance for next year, but you've made a comment a bunch of times that there's a certain period of time it takes sales to turn into revenue. Can you help me think about that? I understand in GlobalView, it could be up to a
componenttext: I understand you're not giving guidance for next year, but you've made a comment a bunch of times that there's a certain period of time it takes sales to turn into revenue. Can you help me think about that? I understand in GlobalView, it could be up to a year to on board a new customer. But one of the areas of strength is small and mid-sized businesses. I was under the assumption that you actually brought those on fairly quickly. Is that accurate and...

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me help you with that. When we report a sales number in the PEO [Professional Employer Organization] or in SBS, that means that they've actually started processing with ADP. When we report a sales number in Major Account, depending upon how many
componenttext: Yes, let me help you with that. When we report a sales number in the PEO [Professional Employer Organization] or in SBS, that means that they've actually started processing with ADP. When we report a sales number in Major Account, depending upon how many applications it typically takes four to six months, maybe as long as eight months in our major accounts or our ASO [Administrative Service Offerings] offerings in that space to actually start processing. And in National Accounts, you should be thinking more like nine months as an average. So business we're selling today in national account won't turn to revenue and best case until the 1st of October, and kind of worst case, a year from now.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on a blended basis though, we should start -- it sounds like it's about six months that we really start to see some and if you drill over the large accounts, it could take a little longer.
componenttext: So on a blended basis though, we should start -- it sounds like it's about six months that we really start to see some and if you drill over the large accounts, it could take a little longer.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Europe is more -- Europe and GlobalView are much more like the National Accounts kind of space, in the six to nine months plus kind of category.
componenttext: Yes, and Europe is more -- Europe and GlobalView are much more like the National Accounts kind of space, in the six to nine months plus kind of category.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And bear in mind, that year-to-date was still down 1% and we were flat in the quarter. But we're encouraged, but it hasn't happened yet. And so the timing into next year rolls out...
componenttext: And bear in mind, that year-to-date was still down 1% and we were flat in the quarter. But we're encouraged, but it hasn't happened yet. And so the timing into next year rolls out...

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, it's pretty straightforward. I mean, we're obviously more encouraged than we've been. A lot of things are turning positive. We're just trying to make sure the folks on the other end of the phone call don't get revenues too far in front of themselves
componenttext: Gary, it's pretty straightforward. I mean, we're obviously more encouraged than we've been. A lot of things are turning positive. We're just trying to make sure the folks on the other end of the phone call don't get revenues too far in front of themselves, as they start thinking about converting sales to actual revenue and what implications that has to the bottom line. And when you couple that with the interest income drag we're going to have for next year, we just trying to be as helpful as possible without getting too far out in front of ourselves.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Totally understood. I guess, let me take that one step further. Chris, you said earlier that due to the rate falling and some of the sales investments, there would be significant pressure on margins. Was that on an absolute basis or you're just saying sig
componenttext: Totally understood. I guess, let me take that one step further. Chris, you said earlier that due to the rate falling and some of the sales investments, there would be significant pressure on margins. Was that on an absolute basis or you're just saying significant pressure from those items? I mean, should we think that margins might be down in fiscal '11 quite a bit? Or is it just pressure relative to the long-term goal of 50 to 75 basis points?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Pressure to the relative goal of 50 basis points year in, year out. I mean, that's an average over a five-year period. Next year is the investment period, and the period where you're ramping in the sales model. So it's relative to that 50 basis points. It
componenttext: Pressure to the relative goal of 50 basis points year in, year out. I mean, that's an average over a five-year period. Next year is the investment period, and the period where you're ramping in the sales model. So it's relative to that 50 basis points. It's not necessarily negative, but it's still too early to...

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and you have to remember, Gary, too, that interest income is very high margin, as you think about that, when you get through all of the ramifications in the ins and outs of ADP's P&L. You have to remember in prior year, we didn't do any merit increas
componenttext: Yes, and you have to remember, Gary, too, that interest income is very high margin, as you think about that, when you get through all of the ramifications in the ins and outs of ADP's P&L. You have to remember in prior year, we didn't do any merit increase. And our bonus payouts were modest based upon our performance and we want to continue to invest in the business in terms of platforms and sales growth and service for the long term. While at the same time, trying to deliver the best results to our shareholders if we can, with keeping long-term objectives in mind. But you shouldn't read any great surprises in terms of our historic business model because you couple those things with some acquisition activity, which we're pleased about. It just puts some pressures on the business, particularly as we go into '11, that would normally be quite as much of a contrast than more normal time.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I could just sneak one more question in. Why wouldn't you, I guess, given how the strong balance sheet and cash flow are, consider accelerating the buybacks? When you throttled back a bit, three or four quarters ago, I think the thought proces
componenttext: And then if I could just sneak one more question in. Why wouldn't you, I guess, given how the strong balance sheet and cash flow are, consider accelerating the buybacks? When you throttled back a bit, three or four quarters ago, I think the thought process or one of the things you said was just challenged markets, want to make sure you're liquid et cetera, et cetera. It seems like we've seen an awful lot of improvement in credit markets and whatnot, and it would seem like the right time from my perspective to buy your stock prior to rate start going up and job growth getting a lot better.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair comment, and the $2 billion of cash that we have is higher than we've said we wanted it to be. We said $1.5 million was the target. Even as things turn around, we've always said that $1 billion is the more appropriate place. So I thi
componenttext: I think that's a fair comment, and the $2 billion of cash that we have is higher than we've said we wanted it to be. We said $1.5 million was the target. Even as things turn around, we've always said that $1 billion is the more appropriate place. So I think you don't do it all right away, you kind of time diversify share repurchases. But as I said, you could see that going forward. You could see us accelerating that to get the cash balance down.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first one relates to RUN and Workforce Now. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about, a little more color in terms of what you're seeing there in terms of the take up in the market? And also, how that's impacting margins and how we should
componenttext: The first one relates to RUN and Workforce Now. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about, a little more color in terms of what you're seeing there in terms of the take up in the market? And also, how that's impacting margins and how we should think about that from a margin perspective? And to your earlier comment, Gary, in terms of, left pocket, right pocket, is there any impact there from that perspective, particularly with regards to RUN?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we are in process with completing the roll out across all regions in RUN, and the product is a real, current state of technology in terms of look and feel, it's a real-time payroll. It's got some nice reporting attributes to it, and it's just doing we
componenttext: No, we are in process with completing the roll out across all regions in RUN, and the product is a real, current state of technology in terms of look and feel, it's a real-time payroll. It's got some nice reporting attributes to it, and it's just doing well in the marketplace with clients, as well as prospects and CPAs and the banking community. So it just really shows well, where the EasyPay was much older product. We're talking about decades older, and didn't demo that well. And so it just -- so the sales force has a lot of confidence in the product now. It's running extremely well. The CPAs and the bankers like it. We're getting a lot of traction in the wholesale market with our CPAs, as we're starting to roll that out. So we're just feeling real good about the product in general and the service people and the sales people are real enthused about it.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a margin difference between that relative to EasyPay?
componenttext: Is there a margin difference between that relative to EasyPay?
